doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/DB/BPER and BPSO Better together deep dive into upside from the merger with BP SondrioBPER and BPSO Better together deep di_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/DB
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/DB

passages.text: Following the definitive outcome of the offer for BP Sondrio (BPSO), which reached \(81\%\) acceptance, and the definition of an action plan that envisages the merger resolution in April 2026 and final integration by 1H26, all the elements are now in place to estimate the fundamentals of the combined entity with BPER.

BPER has also communicated that it plans to publish an update of its business plan - which currently forecasts \(>\) EUR 2bn of net profit in 2027, corresponding to \(\sim 15\%\) ROTE, with an average payout of \(75\%\) and a CET1 of \(>15\%\) - (see our report commenting on this: link) - by 1H26.

In this report, we publish for the first time our combined estimates for the new entity resulting from the merger of BPSO into BPER, also carrying out a detailed analysis of the impact on BPER's capital post- operation and on synergies. In summary, our analysis reveals significant potential in terms of value creation - which we believe should exceed the synergy targets (EUR 290mn after tax, of which EUR 190mn is from costs and EUR 100mn is from revenue) currently forecast by BPER.

Furthermore, we estimate ample room to exceed CET1 guidance at year- end (i.e. \(>15\%\) ) - from which, according to our calculations, optionality arises for potential improvements in the dividend policy.

These arguments, coupled with very robust 2Q reporting from BPER and, above all, BPSO, lead us to confirm our Buy recommendation on the combined entity, increasing the target price for BPER to EUR 12.1 p/s - which corresponds to 2026- 27E adj. P/E of 11.2- 10.6x.

On BPSO, however, despite the excellent reporting and the consequent increase in estimates (approx. \(+5\%\) on average for 2025- 28), we see downside risk relating to the less favorable conditions that could be foreseen for the merger with BPER - expected in April 2026. BPSO can, in fact, be considered today as a proxy for BPER, which has already announced its intention to merge with it. As already disclosed, having crossed the \(67\%\) threshold of the share capital, BPER now has full control of BPSO's Extraordinary General Meeting: as such, it clarified that "the merger may be approved with only the favorable vote" of BPER itself.

Importantly, BPER clarified that the "exchange ratio is determined...with no premium therefore payable to the Issuer's minority shareholders". This clearly poses some downside risk to BPSO shareholders, who should not necessarily be granted the same terms of the expired offer (i.e. 1.45 BPER shares + EUR 1 cash for each BPSO share traded). At current market prices, the ratio of the two stocks is 1.40 (BPER for each BPSO), implying an approx. \(5\%\) discount to the expired offer - with BPSO trading at a 2025- 26E adj. P/E of approx. 10x versus BPER's 8x (pre merger).

Therefore, we see, from now on, a risk that the merger terms that will be overseen by BPER's board of directors for the integration of BPSO will be much less favorable than those implied in the public exchange offer, and may even include a "discount" linked to the lower liquidity of the BPSO stock and/or the change in governance and/ or the absence of a majority premium. In our opinion, there is, therefore, a concrete risk of underperformance, both relative to BPER but also, above all, from a standalone perspective.

We confirm our recommendation of Hold on BPSO with TP of R 11 p/s (2025E- 26E adj. P/E of 8x, P/TE 1.2x) – moving to a stand-alone valuation versus a blended average of M&A valuation and stand-alone valuation that we applied before the closing of the offer).

A brilliant deal, from several points of viewSince its announcement on February 6, the acquisition of BPSO represented a deal with strong rationale from an industrial point of view, via the geographical and business complementarity, and – last but not least – DNA (both banks have roots as cooperative banks and were born as local banks, then grew rapidly through branch openings and/or acquisitions) and governance (see the presence of Unipol as a common shareholder with 20%, as well as a bancassurance partner for both networks in the property and casualty and life insurance sectors).

Through the combination with BPSO, BPER further strengthens its competitive positioning in Lombardy, where it increases its market share on branches from 7% to 17%, adding 379 branches, making BPER the first by number of branches in the region ahead of ISP, which has 15%, and BAMI with 14%.
BPER will significantly increase its exposure also in Milan – where market share will grow from 3% stand-alone to 9%, making BPER the third-largest player in the province.

Last but not least, also at a national level, BPSO's contribution is noteworthy, since it allows BPER to increase its market share by 2%, which should reach 10% – making BPER the third-largest franchise in Italy.
Figure 2: After acquisition of BPSO, BPER's competitive positioning in the key strategic regions of Italy will improve further

RegionBPEBPSOBPE + BPSO%# of branchesMkt Share# of branchesMkt Share# of branchesMkt ShareEmilia-Romagna23911%80%24712%12Friuli-Venezia Giulia20%31%51%0Liguria10819%153%12322%6Lombardia2647%37910%64317%31o/w: Milan283%636%919%4Piemonte735%151%886%4Trentino-Alto Adige30%71%102%0Valle d'Aosta12%35%46%0Veneto452%121%573%3North7356%4424%1,17710%57Center2396%481%2877%14South58213%10%58313%28Total1,5568%4912%2,04710%100
Source : Deutsche Bank, company data

We can say that the acquisition of BPSO represents the final step of a progressive transformation of BPER's network: only a few years ago, BPER was very exposed to the south of the country, but after the acquisition of UBI Branches (2020), Carige (2022), and BPSO, it has evolved into a north- of- Italy- rooted bank.
Figure 5: Breakdown of BPER's loan book by geographic exposure before and after the acquisition of BPSO (2024)

We also believe that a further positive element deriving from the integration of the two entities lies in the possibility for BPER to reach \(100\%\) of Arca SGR, where BPER already has a \(65\%\) stake and BPSO controls \(35\%\) .

The possibility of having full control of Arca SGR should, in our opinion, translate into further value- creation potential, as it will increase the contribution to the group's profit of a capital- light business - which should be valued with a doubledigit multiple. In this regard, we are convinced that even greater disclosure on the divisional performance of the new group through even more detailed segment reporting can contribute to increasing the value of the combined entity through a re- rating of BPER's market multiples.

The only element of uncertainty that- at the time of the announcement of the tender offer - we had highlighted concerned the level of acceptance of the offer, which could have impacted the level of synergies at full capacity (EUR 290mn pre- tax in 2027 based on the company target) and capital. Based on our estimates, for every 5 percentage points of greater acceptance of the offer, BPER would have reported a positive impact of 30bps in terms of CET1.
Figure 6: Sensitivity of BPER's CET1 ratio to different levels of ownership in BPSO
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates

The achievement of \(81\%\) of BPSO's share capital and the goal of completing the merger into BPER by 1H26 - including the migration of the IT system - represents a fundamental step in the economics of the operation because, based on our calculations, it will enable BPER to further increase its capital - replacing minorities with higher- quality capital that is fully accounted for in CET1. Furthermore, given that, in our opinion, the merger will take place at a ratio lower than that of the offer (1.45 BPER shares for each BPSO share, in addition to a cash component of EUR 1), the dilution effect on EPS will be lower than that recorded with the offer.

BPER has always taken a fairly prudent approach in terms of objectives and guidance, both for the short and medium term. We believe that the business combination with BPSO is no exception from this point of view, and we remain convinced that the targets that have been communicated (EUR 190mn of pre- tax synergies with >EUR 2bn of profits to 2027E, corresponding, according to our calculations, to ROTE of \(15\%\) ) are very conservative.

More recently, in the 2Q call, BPER's CEO also stated that at the end of the year, the CET1 of the combined entity should be around \(15\%\) (versus BPER stand- alone: \(16.2\%\) ) - an indication that we interpret as discounting - as per the offer document - \(75\%\) of the restructuring costs (EUR 400mn in total).

Based on our calculations, the \(15\%\) CET1 at the end of 2025 also discounts the full consolidation of Alba Leasing, a company in which BPER holds \(34\%\) and BPSO \(19\%\) (the rest of the shares are held by BAMI with \(39\%\) and Credit Agricole Italia with \(8\%\) ) and is currently consolidated using the equity method.

Alba Leasing is a company with a balance sheet of EUR 5bn and a market share of \(c.7\%\) in Italy - predominantly exposed to equipment leasing, which represents approximately half of the total new production carried out (i.e. EUR 700mn out of EUR 1.67bn of new contracts originated in 2024). Alba Leasing should have accounted for less than \(1\%\) of BPSO's and BPER's profits in 2024.
28 August 2025BanksBPER and BPSO

Figure 7: Alba Leasing is a relatively unprofitable entity, with a 7% market share in the leasing businessSize &amp; Gearing2024Total assets5,303RWA3,996CET110.9%ProfitabilityNet income20ROTE4%GrowthNew business1,677Car323Operating703DistributionShareholder banks66%Other banks8%Other partners26%
Source : Deutsche Bank, company data

Alba Leasing's shareholders provide, in addition to approximately two- thirds of the business in terms of new contracts, part of the funding: for example, in 2024, BPSO approved approx. EUR 411mn in credit lines to Alba Leasing, while we do not find that BPER has contributed to Alba Leasing's funding.

The line- by- line consolidation of Alba Leasing should translate, based on our estimates, into a non- material additional contribution for each line item of the new BPER following acquisition of BPSO, but – with its EUR 4bn of RWA – it generates a capital consumption of 70bps on the CET1. As such, we cannot exclude that BPER will try to avoid such a change in the consolidation perimeter, trying, for instance, to sell part of the stake exceeding 50% to one of the current shareholders and/or to another partner – which could also support further the growth of the company. Such a move, in our view, would avoid a dilution of the capital returns for BPER and a quite significant capital release, something we do not currently incorporate into our estimates.

That said, BPSO will be fully consolidated from 3Q, and we, therefore, expect BPER to report with the results in November the first effect of the business combination, including the purchase price allocation (PPA).

Based on our calculations, BPER should record approx. EUR 758mn of PPA, also benefiting – as we have already highlighted in previous research (see also our report at this link) – from the difference between the fair value of BPSO's assets and liabilities. In particular, BPSO has already recorded in 2Q a positive effect (+EUR 165mn) of the revaluation of the real estate portfolio, while another EUR 100mn was seen in the stand- alone plan to be derived from the renewal of the partnership in merchant acquiring with Nexi, a benefit that BPER will likely report from 2026 and that we have not considered in our calculations.
Figure 8: We calculate a pro-forma CET1 for BPER after acquisition of BPSO of \(15.6\%\) (EUR mn)

Additions5,664o/w: capital increase4,743o/w: BPSO minorities778o/w: Alba leasing minorities142Deductions-1,282o/w: goodwill/badwill-7582Q25BPERBPSOConsolidation adjustmentsCombinedo/w: excess minorities-314RWAs55,59726,5003,99686,093o/w: restructuring costs-210CET9,01804,38113,399Net impact4,381CET1 fully phased %16.2%15.0%-15.6%
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates

Our estimate at the end of the year of the CET1 at \(15\%\) is, therefore, in line with BPER's guidance for the end of 2025, which in any case already seems to exceed the target indicated in the presentation of the deal, when a CET1 target of \(>15\%\) was indicated for 2027.

Furthermore, we expect a strong acceleration in capital generation starting from 2026, due to the organic generation of capital \((>200\) bps/year) and with the completion of the merger with BPSO. In fact, in 1H26, the merger will entail a further strengthening of capital through the issuance of new shares, but at an exchange rate that - as already anticipated by BPER in the press release (see the link here) - will not take as reference the terms of the exchange offer. It is, therefore, probable that the exchange ratio will be more favorable for BPER, limiting any dilutive effect on EPS. Not surprisingly, during the 2Q conference call, BPER's CEO suggested that if the evolution of the CET1 were to exceed expectations, a further increase in the payout is not excluded - which, according to the current integration plan, is expected on average at \(75\%\) .

Importantly, the business combination with BPSO, the relatively high ROTE of the target, and delivery of the synergies will all contribute to stabilizing BPER's organic capital generation after integration at historic peaks, reaching 272bps in 2028.
Figure 9: The business combination with BPSO will contribute to structurally increasing BPER's organic capital generation to historic highs
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates
In particular, at the end of 2026, we expect the CET1 to exceed \(16\%\) and - assuming an optimal level of capital of \(13\%\) - BPER to generate approx. EUR 1.5 p/s of capital

surplus \((17\%)\) of the market cap) - a level that could further increase \((+1\%)\) if including the effects of the extension of the partnership on merchant acquiring on the terms established by BPSO in its business plan (EUR 100mn, corresponding to EUR 0.05 p/s in 2026).
Figure 10:Sensitivity of excess capital to different levels of CET1 (EUR p/s)
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates
Figure 11: Sensitivity of excess capital to different levels of CET1 (% of the market cap)
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates

In addition to a potential evolution of the CET1 better than guidance and expectations, in our opinion, the estimates of synergies deriving from the integration of BPSO into BPER have also been estimated prudently. BPER's plan currently envisages the following:
EUR 190mn of cost synergies (pre- tax), equal to \(30\%\) of BPSO's base. EUR 100mn of revenue synergies (pre- tax), equal to \(6\%\) of BPSO's base.

From a relative point of view, the synergies that BPER expects to obtain with the merger of BPSO are in line with the average reported in similar acquisition operations - but we have good reasons to believe that these objectives will be revised upward and/or that BPER will reach a level of synergies well above that seen both on costs and on revenue.
Our conviction, as far as cost savings are concerned, is based on some considerations, specifically the following:

1. As far as we know, in the recent past, BPSO has never implemented any incentivized exit plan/early retirement plan for employees. Furthermore, in recent years, the total number of BPSO FTEs has never decreased. The same applies to branches that, on a like-for-like basis, have always increased year-on-year despite BPSO having never carried out any acquisitions and/or changes in scope in the past 10 years.
Figure 12: In each of the past 15 years, BPSO has increased the number of branches and FTEs
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates,company data
For this reason, we believe that, compared with other entities that have implemented staff- and branch- reduction plans over time, BPSO can guarantee BPER a wider scope for efficiency improvement.

1. BPER expects to complete the integration of BPSO within a reasonably short time, i.e. by 1H26. During the 2Q conference call, BPER's CEO stated that the completion of the integration should be understood as the migration of the networks to the target IT system – which has not yet been identified, according to what we understood from the conference call, but should reasonably be represented by that of BPER. A rapid migration of the IT system, which in the past in the event of a merger of equals took even a few years, enables accelerating the achievement of synergies and improving processes – with benefits in terms of efficiency and more generally cost reduction. Not a negligible effect, the rapid migration of IT systems also reduces the risk of revenue disruption.

2. Based on the feedback from the conference call on the presentation of the operation on February 6, BPER expects 40% of cost synergies (i.e. approx. EUR 80mn) to be derived from personnel savings and the remainder (EUR 100mn) from "savings from rationalization and optimization of central functions, optimization of branches and savings on investments in technology and IT". However, in our opinion, cost synergies on administrative expenses can be exceeded by at least 20% by significantly reducing BPSO's legal and consulting expenses (EUR 113mn in 2024, which represents 40% of total G&A versus 28% for BPER), IT expenses (EUR 70mn), and RE expenses (EUR 39mn in 2024) with associated taxes. We also expect a significant reduction in amortizations (EUR 70mn/year for BPSO stand-alone), for a total of cost synergies from administrative expenses of EUR 215mn (in 2028E).
28 August 2025  Banks  BPER and BPSO
Figure 13: In relative terms, BPSO has allocated more resources to consulting expenses, which should be easier to reduce (2024)
Source : Deutsche Bank estimates, company data
The table below shows our forecasts for the evolution of the cost bases of BPER and BPSO until 2028.
Figure 14: After the integration of BPSO, we expect the downward trend of BPER's cost base to accelerate and result in a better performance in terms of synergies than targeted (EUR mn)

Legend: BPER staff costs excluding cost of early retirements in 2024 BPER depreciation in 2024 include around EUR 62mn of one-off related to write-off of invest BPSO and BPER G&A excluding direct and indirect taxes, stamp duties and bank levies
Source: Deutsche Bank estimates, company data

Furthermore, we believe that the combined entity can generate a level of revenue synergies that can exceed the targets presented in February, i.e. EUR 100mn: we expect BPER to also revise this guidance upward with the updated presentation of the BPSO integration business plan in 1H26. In our opinion, in fact, BPER has underestimated the revenue potential that can be derived from using, for example, BPSO's best practices on its customers. Based on our calculations, at the end of 2024, BPSO had over 1,800 corporate customers with EUR 8bn of loans in addition to 75k SME customers (with loans of EUR 10.4bn): one of BPSO's characteristics has been the contribution derived from foreign exchange activity with these customers; in 2Q, it generated approximately EUR 7mn of commissions, classified under the item "trading".

This item - which, in our opinion, largely reflects client- driven activity in foreign exchange carried out by the bank in the past five years - has shown notable stability at around EUR 30mn/year, with the exception of FY24, when BPSO reported EUR 93mn in profit (a figure that likely includes some one- offs/a non- recurring
Figure 15: Contribution of client-driven FX business has proved to be a relatively stable revenue stream for BPSO over time (EUR mn)

On the other hand, we do not find that this business is particularly developed by BPER or that it is in the same dimension as for BPSO: for this reason, we think that there is - on BPER's export- oriented customers - ample room to increase the contribution of foreign exchange hedges, which must be represented as a further area of synergy in the future.

A further area in which BPSO can generate synergies, in our opinion, concerns the alignment in terms of penetration of insurance products: based on our calculations, BPSO's indirect collection features significantly lower penetration versus BPER's in terms of insurance contracts; this translates into a lower contribution of fees from this business.
Figure 16: Insurance benchmarking - BPER has significantly higher penetration of insurance products than BPSO

As a matter of fact, in 2024, fees derived from these products represented only \(8\%\) of BPSO's total fees, compared to \(11\%\) of BPER's. BPSO, apparently, has less cross- selling than BPER - especially, for instance, in bancassurance products. We note that insurance policies represent \(\sim 16\%\) of BPER's stock of indirect collection (i.e. 3x above BPSO's \(4\%\) ). We also believe that this gap underestimates the actual penetration of insurance policies in BPER's product mix, as BPER stocks are inflated by the consolidation of Arca's AUM, part of which also relates to BPSO's network.
In contrast, according to our calculations, BPSO derives a slightly higher margin on insurance reserves than BPER - this may reflect a different product mix.
Assuming a convergence of productivity in terms of placement of life- insurance products to the same standards as BPER's (also in terms of pricing), based on 2024

data, BPSO could be in a position to generate around EUR 3.6bn of additional insurance product inflows, increasing fee income by around EUR 50mn. In turn, such an assumption would represent approx. \(50\%\) of the targeted EUR 100mn in revenue synergies.
Figure 17:Alignment of the penetration of insurance policies within BPSO's indirect funding could generate a significant portion of the targeted revenue synergies (EUR mn)

2021202220232024BPERTotal gross fees1,8452,1172,1582,298Fees on insurance products167217233253% penetration9%10%11%11%Margin (bps)8593115120Indirect collection146,986138,875149,021132,000Insurance policies19,60323,33920,18121,000% penetration13%17%14%16%BPSOTotal gross fees322401424455Fees on insurance products28283236% penetration9%7%8%8%Margin (bps)148142152164Indirect collection42,90041,00048,40054,300Insurance policies1,9002,0002,1002,200% penetration4%5%4%4%Target penetration11%Additional stock4,239Margin (bps)120Incremental fees on insurance policies51% of target revenue synergies51%
Source : Deutsche Bank estimates, company data

Lastly, in our view, with the integration of BPSO, BPER would also be able to report synergies in the cost of funding, optimizing BPSO's ALM structure. BPSO has in fact been historically exposed to funding toward some institutional counterparties (pension funds, etc.) to which it recognizes a certain mark- up compared to the cost of retail funding.

BPSO does not disclose the amount of funding generated by these clients, but we can have a relatively precise indication, as we note that BPSO disclosed EUR 32bn (as of 1Q25) of "core direct customer funding" as the amount of funding net of repos and funding from institutional counterparts (slide 13 of BPSO's 2Q results presentation). As such, with around EUR 1.7bn of repos outstanding (as of 1Q25), we derive that around EUR 4bn is represented by funding from institutional counterparts that, in our view, largely represents those large institutions. We believe that BPSO can replace at least part of this funding leveraging BPER's abundant LTD ratio – which was 86% at the end of 1H25. Assuming a partial reduction (- EUR 3bn) of this funding source, and replaced with BPER's liquidity, we calculate a potential benefit in terms of cost of funding from the combination of BPSO with BPER of around EUR 36mn, i.e. 36% of the total revenue synergy target for 2027.
Figure 18: Optimization of BPSO's funding mix may generate EUR 36mn of revenue synergies (EUR mn)

2Q25BPERBPSOCombinedOptimizationPro-formaClient loans92,70136,593129,2940129,294Customer deposits107,42638,571145,997142,997142,997o/w: institutional counterparts04,0694,069-3,0001,069Customer deposits excl. Institutional counterparts107,42634,502141,928141,928141,928LTD ratio86%95%89%-90%LTD ratio excl. institutional counterparts86%106%91%91%Mark-up on excess liquidity-1.13%----Mark-down on funding with institutional counterparts-0.07%---Net impact on spread1.20%Impact on NII36% of 2026E NII0.9%% of target revenue synergies36%
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates

In summary, we calculate that- by 2027- BPER could reach EUR 100mn in revenue synergies from the combination with BPSO and significantly exceed this amount in 2028, when we expect a positive impact of EUR 161mn.
Figure 19: Details and phasing of the revenue synergies (EUR mn)
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates

Our analysis so far has provided more than an argument to demonstrate that the targeted synergies (EUR 190mn in costs and EUR 100mn in revenue in 2027) are quite conservative or too conservative: being prudent or prudently realistic is the main feature of BPER's corporate culture and DNA, in our view.

According to our numbers, synergies could instead reach EUR 514mn in 2028 (at full steam) or EUR 362mn in 2027, i.e. significantly above the EUR 290mn management target - with cost savings on G&A expenses representing the area where we see most of the upside potential. That said, other than due to evident room to do better in terms of costs and revenue, we are also convinced that management will revise upward the \(>EUR\) 2bn net income target in 2027, also incorporating a better underlying performance from BPSO.

As a matter of fact (see also our report here), 2Q results proved to be \(2\%\) ahead of Deutsche Bank's estimates (DBe) and \(6\%\) above consensus, with NII (+4% q/q) proving to be far more resilient than expected via a fine- tuning of the cost of funding and even net of some non- recurring items.

Following the better reporting in 2Q, we increase by an average of approx. \(6\%\) BPSO's 2025- 28 estimates, and now assume net income of around EUR 600mn in the next couple of years; this implies a quarterly run rate of EUR 150mn, which compares with an adjusted bottom line of EUR 160mn in 2Q.
Figure 20: After the good reporting in 2Q, we increase by an average of \(6\%\) BPSO's 2025-28 estimates (EUR mn)
Source : Deutsche Bank estimates

That said, if we interpret BPER's >EUR 2bn net income target in 2027 after the merger with BPSO as a bottom line in the region of EUR 2.2bn and incorporate the EUR 290mn of pre- tax synergies (EUR 200mn after tax), we obtain an implied contribution to profit of the new group by BPSO of "only" EUR 537mn, i.e. \(10\%\) below our updated estimates.
Figure 21: BPSO's contribution implied in BPER's 2027 net income target of \(>\)EUR 2bn is very low, in our view (EUR mn)

2027EBPER post integration with BPSOImplied contribution by BPSOSynergiesBPER stand aloneTotal income&gt; EUR 7bn1,640100~ EUR 5.5bnC/I ratio~45%n.a.n.a.~50%Pre-provision profit~ EUR 4bn610290EUR 3.1Net profit&gt; EUR 2bn537203~ EUR 1.5bnPayout (average)75%--~75%CET1 %&gt; 15%--&gt;14.5%ROTE&gt; 15%--&lt;16%
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates,company data

Following the acquisition of control of BPSO, we expect BPER to be able to have a better idea of the upside potential of its target, resulting in an upgrade of its contribution to profit of the new group; this will likely be unveiled with the new business plan in 1H26.

While our estimates exceed the target synergies for 2027 only by c. \(10\%\) , the full impact of managerial actions will be visible in 2028, when we expect EUR 356mn of cost savings due to the phasing out of the early retirement scheme, while revenue synergies should remain stable at EUR 124mn.
Figure 22: We expect synergies to significantly exceed BPER's guidance in 2028 but to be higher than budgeted in 2027 (EUR mn)

RevenuesDBE (2027E)Company TargetDBE (2028E)Increased penetration of insurance products51n.a.51Optimization of funding mix36n.a.36Increase penetration of FX services50n.a.50Other20n.a.20Subtotal157100157% of BPSO base9%6%9%CostsDBE (2027E)Company TargetDBE (2028E)Staff76114185G&amp;A9976142Depreciation30n.a.30Subtotal205190356% of BPSO base32%30%56%Total synergies362290514
Source:Deutsche Bank estimates,company data
Following the final results of the exchange offer on BPSO, we are now in a position to finalize the new estimates for BPER.

For 2027, we assume net income of EUR 2,405 mn, corresponding to ROTE of 18%, well ahead of the company target of >EUR 2bn. We expect the full effect of cost synergies to be visible only in 2028, resulting in a further acceleration of the bottom line to EUR 2.6bn (17.9% ROTE) – with BPER sitting on an excess capital position given a CET1 of 17.1%.

We derive our new target price via a Gordon Growth Model (GGM), using an optimal CET1 of 13.5%, with ROTE at normalized gearing (2028E) of 23% – and obtain a new target price of EUR 12.1 – corresponding to 2026- 27E adj. P/E of 11- 10x.
Figure 23: Target price calculation (EUR)

2028EROTE18.0%ROTE @ optimal gearing23.3%Excess capital ps1.6K(e)12.5%g0.5%Implied P/TE (x)1.9xTE ps @ optimal gearing7.2Subtotal Terminal value13.9PV of the terminal value9.8PV the 2025-27 DPS1.8P/TE of the excess capital0.2xPV of the excess capital0.3Target price12.1Current price9.0Upside / downside34%Implied multiples2026E2027E 2028EAdj P/E11.2x10.6x 9.6xP/TE1.7x1.7x 1.7x
Source : Deutsche Bank estimates
We reiterate our Buy rating on BPER based on the following:

1. After the combination with BPSO, BPER will emerge as a more integrated and stronger franchise from a competitive standpoint. As such, we expect a re-rating of market multiples (versus the current 2026- 27E adj. P/E of 8.5- 7.8x) compared with the historical average of 9.3- 8.8x. The re-rating should, in our view, also be supported by a better earnings profile, as BPER will count a higher contribution to the bottom line from the AM business, specialized product factories, and operations abroad (Switzerland)
Figure 24: BPER's historical P/E
Source:Bloomberg Finance LP

2. We also expect BPER to benefit from a "scarcity effect" after the deal. With a pro- forma market cap of >EUR 17bn, the new entity should represent a more viable investment option for large investors with a long-term horizon aiming for exposure to a much larger franchise with a plain-vanilla business model and two-thirds of the loan portfolio going toward retail, small business, and mid-corporate clients (mainly in the north of Italy), a low risk-profile, and a solid capital position
3. The deal with BPSO enables accelerating BPER's growth versus a stand-alone condition, with an EPS CAGR rising from 2% to c.6%, which should also support a re-rating of market multiples.

4. We expect positive news flow in terms of capital accumulation, with a stronger-than-budgeted trajectory in terms of CET1, which paves the way for optionality value in terms of dividend distributions. As a matter of fact, BPER's current payout target of "only" 75% of the profits should be seen as a base-case scenario: we cannot exclude an improvement in the future – given the strong capital generation expected in the coming years – which may result in an even more appealing dividend yield (from 8-10% to approx. 12%).

Despite strong reporting from BPSO, we confirm our Hold rating (TP: EUR 11): we now value the stock on a stand-alone basis given the completion of the tender offer by BPER via a sum-of-the-parts approach.

From a business- mix standpoint, BPSO's main elements include (a) full control of specialty finance company Factorit and of BP Suisse, a retail banking business based in Lugano (CH), and (b) a \(34\%\) stake in AM company Arca SGR, a JV with BPE. These product companies provide a relatively stable contribution to the group's bottom line, i.e. \(>20\%\) in the past few years. The stand- alone business plan projects ROTE of \(>14\%\) in 2027, leveraging relatively stable NII and, in our view, quite an aggressive assumption in terms of expansion of the AM/bancassurance business. Following the successful completion of a tender offer, BPSO is now controlled by the \(81\%\) stake of a domestic competitor, which has already announced the intention to merge BPSO by 1H26 and complete the integration of the group.

Following the successful completion of the tender offer by the domestic competitor, we move our valuation of BPSO from a blended average (stand- alone target price, based on a sum- of- the- parts model and an M&A valuation, assuming a valuation on the terms envisaged by the tender) to a sum- of- the- parts model, which enables us to capture the contribution of the different business units to the value created on a stand- alone basis.

BPSO's upside risk is represented by a merger - already announced by the controlling shareholder by 1H26 - on more favorable terms than those implied by current valuations. Upside risk could also be generated by a better- than- expected distribution policy and/or a significant outperformance in terms of earnings generation compared with stand- alone targets. Downside risks are represented by a worse- than- expected evolution of the NII, by a slowdown in the contribution of client- driven activity on FX and by an unexpected weakening in the asset quality.

The Equity Rating Dispersion Chart depicts the following:

The proportion of recommendations that are rated "buy", "sell" and "hold" over the previous 12 months. This is shown for securities issued in the stated region e.g. "Europe Universe". See rating definitions below. This is represented by the "Companies Covered" bars in the chart. The percentage value displayed above the bar is the proportion as a percentage. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "buy" / "Companies Covered" bar means that \(50\%\) of DB's equity research covered companies over the past 12 months have a "buy" rating.
Next to each of the three respective bars showing the proportion of "buy", "sell" and "hold" recommendations we provide two additional bars to show:

- The proportion of "buy", "sell" or "hold recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates provided MIFID Investment or Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. This is represented in the "MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the given rating where DB has also provided MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated have also received MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services from DB.

- The proportion of "buy" (or "sell" or "hold) recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates has provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months for which it has received compensation. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the stated rating where DB has also provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ Investment Banking relationship" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated also have an Investment Banking Relationship with DB.
Buy: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors buy the stock.
Sell: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors sell the stock.
Hold: We take a neutral view on the stock 12- months out and, based on this time horizon, do not recommend either a Buy or Sell.
TSR = Total Shareholder Return. Percentage change in share price from current price to projected target price plus projected dividend yield

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

As a result of the high degree of leverage obtainable in futures and options trading, losses may be incurred that are greater than the amount of funds initially deposited - up to theoretically unlimited losses. Investors in securities such as ADRs, whose values are affected by the currency of an underlying security, effectively assume currency risk.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.

The method for computing individual E,S,G and composite ESG scores set forth herein is a novel method developed by the Research department within Deutsche Bank AG, computed using a systematic approach without human intervention. Different data providers, market sectors and geographies approach ESG analysis and incorporate the findings in a variety of ways. As such, the ESG scores referred to herein may differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other ESG data providers in the market and may also differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other divisions within the Deutsche Bank Group. Such ESG scores also differ from other ratings and rankings that have historically been applied in research reports published by Deutsche Bank AG. Further, such ESG scores do not represent a formal or official view of Deutsche Bank AG. It should be noted that the decision to incorporate ESG factors into any investment strategy may inhibit the ability to participate in certain investment opportunities that otherwise would be consistent with your investment objective and other principal investment strategies. The returns on a portfolio consisting primarily of sustainable investments may be lower or higher than portfolios where ESG factors, exclusions, or other sustainability issues are not considered, and the investment opportunities available to such portfolios may differ. Companies may not necessarily meet high performance standards on all aspects of ESG or sustainable investing issues; there is also no guarantee that any company will meet expectations in connection with corporate responsibility, sustainability, and/or impact performance.
